questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with localized pain, which is gradual in onset and worsened over time. X-ray showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
Identify the following condition
A 35 year old man presented with a gradual progressive swelling, and was diagnosed with Adamantinoma. Which of the following bones is typically affected by this tumor?
questions.explanation:
Adamantinoma

About
  • Rare, low-grade malignant bone tumors of uncertain histogenesis
  • Commonly affects the anterior metaphysis and diaphysis tibia, close to the skin surface.
  • Immunohistochemical studies suggest epithelial origin.
  • Commonly affects individuals aged 20-40 years.

Histopathology
  • Macroscopic: Well-defined, lobulated cortical tumors with yellowish-gray appearance and possible cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic: Biphasic composition (epithelial and osteofibrous components) with basaloid, tubular, spindle-cell, squamous, and osteofibrous dysplasia-like patterns.
  • Immunohistochemistry:
    • Epithelial cells: Positive for keratin, EMA, vimentin, p63, podoplanin.
    • Fibrous component: Positive for vimentin.
    • Expression of EGF, EGFR (epithelial), FGF2, FGFR1 (both components).

Clinical Features
  • Prolonged clinical course with slow-growing swelling, possible pain, bone deformities, or pathological fractures (~23%).
  • Rarely involves neurological deficits when the spine is affected.
  • Metastases commonly involve lungs, lymph nodes, or spine.

Evaluation
  • X-ray: Well-circumscribed, multilobulated, osteolytic cortical tumor with a "soap-bubble" appearance.
  • CT Scan: Assesses soft tissue extension and cortical involvement.
  • MRI: Locoregional staging; visualizes tumor margins, cortical involvement, and soft tissue extension.

Treatment
  • Wide Resection: En bloc removal with wide margins preferred.
  • Metastasectomy: First-line for pulmonary recurrences.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old female who presents with a tumor located at the knee joint, as shown in the provided biopsy-image?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > Proximal tibia > Distal radius > Sacrum

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is experiencing pain in the area surrounding his knee joint. The following lesion visible on the X-ray is seen extending from the distal femur to the terminal end. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Types base on Clinical Setting 

Primary osteosarcoma 

  • No known pre-malignant conditions related to it. 
  • Age group: 15-25 years

Secondary osteosarcoma 

  • Pre-malignant conditions are often associated with it. 
  • Paget's disease, multiple enchondromatosis, fibrous dysplasia, irradiation to bones, multiple osteochondroma. 
  • Older age group

questions.explanation:
Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.

Radiology

Histo- pathology

questions.text: Match the following with their most appropriate mode of management: 1. Osteosarcoma 2. Simple bone cyst 3. Giant cell tumor 4. Osteoid osteoma A. Wide excision B. Curettage C. Radiofrequency ablation D. Intralesional steroid
questions.explanation:
Condition

Features and Findings

Treatment

Osteosarcoma
  • A malignant bone tumor, commonly affecting the metaphyses of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia).
  • It most frequently occurs in adolescents and young adults. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass.
  • X-rays typically show a sunburst appearance with mixed lytic and sclerotic areas.
  • Surgical resection (amputation or limb-sparing surgery), followed by chemotherapy.
  • Radiation therapy is rarely used.

Simple Bone Cyst

  • A benign, fluid-filled cyst, often occurring in the proximal humerus or femur.
  • It is typically asymptomatic
  • On X-ray, it appears as a well-defined, cystic lesion with a thin cortical rim.
  • Often occurs in children and adolescents.
  • Aspiration and steroid injection, or curettage with bone grafting if recurrent fractures occur.
  • Surgical intervention is usually necessary if there is risk of fracture.

Giant Cell Tumor

  • A benign, locally aggressive tumor that typically occurs in the epiphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • It is most common in young adults.
  • Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes joint dysfunction.
  • X-rays show a lytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance.
  • Curettage with bone grafting or chemical adjuvants (e.g., phenol). Wide resection for larger or more aggressive tumors..

Osteoid Osteoma
  • A benign bone tumor that most commonly affects the femur or tibia. It typically occurs in adolescents or young adults.
  • Characterized by a small, well-circumscribed lesion with a central nidus on X-ray.
  • Symptoms include localized pain, especially at night, that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus is the standard treatment. Radiofrequency ablation can be used
  • Pain is often well-controlled with NSAIDs until definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with knee pain. The x-ray of his knee joint is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
A 20-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the index finger around the proximal phalanx. An X-ray was done, and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Fracture after trivial fall in elderly patient. Identify the cause?
questions.explanation:
Common Metastatic Tumors
  • Lung carcinoma (male)
  • Breast carcinoma (female)
  • Prostate carcinoma (Osteoblastic)
  • Thyroid carcinoma

Clinical Features
  • Known Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain (common in spine, ribs, extremities)
    • Pathological fracture (common in spine and hip)
 
  • Unknown Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain leading to destructive lesion diagnosis
    • Pathological fracture due to weakened bone

Malignancies Presenting with Silent Primary
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Bladder carcinoma

Common Sites of Metastasis
  • Vertebral bodies
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis (Option A)
  • Humerus
  • Femur
  • Uncommon distal to elbow and knee

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with pain and swelling over the distal radius. X-ray shows an expansile lytic lesion in the metaphysis. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) reveals a bloody aspirate with hemosiderin-laden macrophages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)

Age

Primarily affects children and teenagers

Most common in young adults (15-35 years)

Gender

Equal distribution between males and females

More common in females (Female: Male ratio 1.5:1)

Location

Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus), spine

Epiphyses of long bones (lower end of femur, upper end of tibia)

Symptoms

Pain and swelling; spinal lesions may cause neurological issues

Swelling without pain; late stages show joint limitation and pathological fracture

Histology
  • FNAC: Hemosiderin +
  • Blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae
  • FNAC: No hemosiderin
  • Abundant giant cells with multiple nuclei (>150), spindle cells indicating malignancy

Radiology

Osteolytic lesion, multiple septations and fluid-fluid levels on MRI

Thin septa with soap-bubble appearance on X-ray, cortex thin and expanded, no periosteal reaction

Treatment

Curettage, debridement, and in some cases radiation (cautiously)

Surgical excision with PMMA or bone grafting; Denosumab and bisphosphonates as adjunct therapy

questions.text: Codman's triangle is seen in which of the following conditions?

A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is a complication of intermittent administration of teriparatide?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Osteosarcoma

questions.text: A patient has a painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone . X-ray done shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct option C - Osteoch

  X-ray finding
Osteochondroma

Bony outgrowth with a cartilage cap
Osteosarcoma

Destructive and irregular lesion with aggressive features such as periosteal reaction, cortical destruction and soft tissue extension
Multiple myeloma Lytic lesions throughout the bone, often referred to as "punched-out" lesions
Osteoid osteoma

Small radiolucent nidus surrounded by dense sclerotic bone

questions.text: A 14 year old male presents with a mushroom like tumor in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features suggest its malignant transformation?

options.label: B
options.text: Bone marrow is continuous with the parent bone

options.label: C
options.text: The cartilaginous growth goes towards the joint

questions.explanation:
Description
  • Also known as Exostosis
  • Most common primary benign bone tumor (but not a true bone tumor)
  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, lower end of femur > upper end of tibia

Types
  • Solitary Osteochondroma
  • Multiple Osteochondromas (MO)

Clinical features
  • Painless mass- most common presentation
  • Pain: secondary to bursa formation/fracture/nerve compression

Radiographic Appearance
  • X-ray: Pedunculated cauliflower-like mass originating from metaphysis
  • MRI: used to assess cartilage thickness

Malignant transformation
  • Very rare
  • MRI showing cartilage thickness > 2 cms suggests malignant transformation (Option A)

Management
  • Asymptomatic cases: No treatment required
  • Symptomatic cases: Excision with biopsy

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 17-year-old male patient who visits the clinic with a painless lump on the outer side of his left knee, as depicted in the radiograph provided?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

Painful bursa formation

Due to friction over the osteochondroma.

Activity-related discomfort

General discomfort with movement.

Nerve compression

Rare, may cause neuropathic symptoms.

Fracture

Uncommon, results in sudden pain.

Malignant transformation

Rare progression to chondrosarcoma, more likely with a cartilage cap >1.5 cm.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the X-ray image of the affected wrist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - O

questions.text: A child presents with difficulty in walking. On biopsy of the hip , some cells with grooved nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm are present. Which investigation would you order next?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - CD1a Mark

Immunohistochemistry
  • Helps identify the presence of specific markers, such as CD1a, Langerin, S-100 protein, which are characteristic of Langerhans cells

Biopsy
  • Confirms the diagnosis and identifies Langerhans cells in affected tissues. Can be performed on skin, bone, or other involved organs.

Imaging
  • Evaluates the extent and involvement of organs. Common imaging modalities include
  • X-ray; SKULL: solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion, geographic skull
  • Spine: vertebra plana
  • Floating Tooth
  • Mandible: irregular radiolucent area involving superficial alveolar bone.
  •  CT scan, MRI, and PET scan.

Complete blood count
  • Detects abnormalities in blood cell counts, such as anemia or leukocytosis.

questions.text: The treatment for the condition given below is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Extended Curettage with Autog

Definition
  • Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone is a locally aggressive, potentially benign neoplasm characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells. It typically occurs in the epiphysis (ends) of long bones.
Epidemiology
  • Most commonly affects individuals between the ages of 20 and 40. - Slight female predilection.
Location
  • Typically found in the metaphysis (near the joint) of long bones, especially around the knee. - Common sites include the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius.
Pathogenesis
  • The exact cause is not well understood, but there is a correlation with mutations in the H3F3A gene - Increased expression of RANKL (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor Kappa-B Ligand) plays a role in the pathogenesis.
Clinical Presentation
  • Pain: Persistent pain at the site of the lesion, often worsening at night. - Swelling: Localized swelling or a palpable mass may be present. - Pathological Fractures: Weakening of the bone may lead to fractures.
Radiographic Features
  • Lytic Lesion: On X-rays, GCT appears as a lytic (lucent) lesion with well-defined borders. - Eccentric Location: Typically eccentrically located in the metaphysis, extending to the epiphysis.
Histopathology
  • Giant Cells: Numerous multinucleated giant cells surrounded by mononuclear stromal cells. - Mitotic Activity: Variable, with higher mitotic activity suggesting a more aggressive course.
Diagnosis
  • Imaging studies, including X-rays, CT scans, and MRI, help in initial diagnosis. - Confirmation through histopathological examination of a biopsy.
Treatment
  • Curettage and Bone Grafting: Common surgical approach involving removal of the tumor and filling the cavity with bone graft. - Denosumab: Monoclonal antibody therapy used in certain cases, particularly when surgery is challenging or to reduce recurrence. - En Bloc Resection: In cases of extensive involvement or recurrence.
Prognosis
  • Generally good with appropriate treatment, but recurrence is possible, especially in cases with incomplete excision.
    - Pulmonary metastasis is rare but can occur in aggressive cases.
Complications
  • Local Recurrence: More likely with incomplete excision. - Fractures: Weakening of bone may lead to pathological fractures. - Pulmonary Metastasis: Rare, but can occur in aggressive cases.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.explanation:

Orthopedic Oncology Conditions

Codman's triangle

Enchondroma

Metastatic bone lesions

Multiple lucent lesions

Multiple myeloma

Linear, vertical, or horizontal striations

Fibrosarcoma

Ill-defined, moth-eaten appearance

Chondrosarcoma

questions.correct_answer: A. Extended curettage and bone grafting

questions.explanation: Correct Option D - T
